awd_abstract_narration:
Convexity in continuous domains has been known to be a powerful property and an important tool for more than a century. Thanks to several independent recent developments in the topics of optimal transport, partial differential equations, geometric and functional analysis, the interplay of convexity and curvature has further enriched the understanding of several topics in probability and analysis.  While convexity has been developed through the important notion of submodularity in discrete settings, curvature remains elusive. In the past five years, the investigator and various collaborators have introduced discrete notions of the so-called Ricci curvature in Markov chains and graphs and derived several interesting consequences. However, much remains to be understood and developed in terms of convexity and curvature in discrete spaces. Identifying suitable applications in mathematics and computer science first will be an important guiding principle in developing any new theory.
 
In discrete probability, the Ahlswede-Daykin Four Functions Theorem has had numerous applications (by way of the FKG inequality and other consequences) and similarly the Prekopa-Leindler inequality has been instrumental in deepening the understanding of the geometric and functional inequalities, while expanding the applications of the (equivalent) Brunn-Minkowski inequality to branches of probability, analysis and PDEs.  A main technical objective of this project is to relate these two seminal results, using optimal transport-based couplings, and derive refined versions of each inequality. Other aspects include deriving higher-order Buser inequalities relating the k-th eigenvalue of the Laplacian to the higher-order (multipartite) Cheeger isoperimetric constant, under additional assumptions on volume growth and/or discrete curvature. The project also involves several specific problems for investigation with postdoctoral fellows and students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Some of the main outcomes are as follows. All have appeared in publications and are available through the math arxiv:

1) In discrete probability, the Ahlswede-Daykin Four Functions Theorem (1978) has had numerous applications (by way of the FKG inequality and others) and similarly the Prekopa-Leindler inequality (1972-73) has been instrumental in deepening the understanding of the geometric and functional inequalities, while expanding the applications of the (equivalent) Brunn-Minkowski inequality to branches of probability, analysis and PDEs. 

In continued collaboration with the French mathematicians Nathael Gozlan, Cyril Roberto and Paul-Marie Samson, the PI developed an optimal transport-minded approach to certain discrete versions of the Prekopa-Leindler Inequality. These include the Four Functions Theorem and a recent result of Klartag and Lehec (2019) on the set of integers. Both inequalities were derived as a consequence of the stronger displacement convexity of entropy on the set of integers. 

2)  In joint work with Christian Borgs,  Jennifer Chayes, Tyler Helmuth and Will Perkins, the PI worked on sampling and counting algorithms for the q-state Potts model on Z^d at all temperatures. In particular, for d ≥ 2 and all q ≥ q_0(d), the work provides an efficient algorithm to approximately sample from the q-color Potts and random cluster models on the torus (Z/nZ)^d for any inverse temperature β. This stands in contrast to Markov chain mixing time results which say that the Glauber dynamics mix (exponentially) slowly  below the critical temperature and that the Swendsen?Wang dynamics also mix slowly  at the critical temperature.

3) In joint work with Nikhil Bansal and Jatin Garg and the PI's student Majid Farhadi, the PI studied the generalized min sum set cover (GMSSC) problem, a vast generalization of the set cover and min sum set cover problems. One is given a collection of hyperedges with arbitrary covering requirements ? integers k_e, for each hyperedge e, and the goal is to find an ordering of the vertices to minimize the total cover time of the hyperedges; a hyperedge e is considered covered by the first time when k_e many of its vertices appear in the ordering. The main result is a 4.642 approximation algorithm for the GMSSC, coming close to the best possible bound of 4, already for the classical special case (with all k_e=1) of min sum set cover (MSSC), introduced and studied by the PI in joint work with Uriel Feige and Laszlo Lovasz in 2004. The new result improves upon the previous best known bound of 12.4  due to Im, Sviridenko and van der Zwaan (2014). As part of the analysis of our algorithm,  a new  inequality on the lower tail of a sum of independent Bernoulli random variables is derived, which is of independent interest and potential broader utility. Another well-known special case is the min sum vertex cover(MSVC) problem, in which the input hypergraph is a graph and as in MSSC, k_e = 1, for every edge e. A new bound of  16/9-approximation is provided for MSVC, and a matching integrality gap for the natural LP relaxation is also established.  This improves upon the previous best 1.999946 approximation of Barenholz, Feige and Peleg (2006). 

The PI has mentored, collaborated and published with several undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs. These collaborations have included several women and underrepresented minorities in mathematical sciences. The students and postdocs have also been placed in academia as well as industry, and government research labs.
